docs.lead_paragraph: After spending 14 years and $4.5 billion on studies, the Energy Department said today that it would recommend that Yucca Mountain, a barren volcanic structure about 90 miles from Las Vegas, be used to bury thousands of tons of highly radioactive nuclear waste from power plants and nuclear weapons factories. The department has been trying for decades to find a place to dispose of the waste piling up at its bomb factories and civilian power plants, and today's decision is only one step in a tortuous process with an outcome that is still uncertain.
docs.abstract: Energy Dept will recommend that Yucca Mountain, Nev, be used to bury thousands of tons of highly radioactive nucear waste from power plants and nuclear weapons factories; decision comes after 14 years and $4.5 billion in studies; it is first time department says publicly that it can make scientific case that waste can be secured at Yucca Mountain; project faces substantial technical, legal and political challenges, and could be derailed by either house of Congress, courts or engineering problems; project is expected to cost more than $40 billion; site is barren volcanic structure 90 miles from Las Vegas; Energy Sec Spencer Abraham notes need to enhance protection against terrorist attacks by consolidating and moving nuclear wastes to underground location far from population centers; photo (M)

docs.snippet: History has a way of cleaning itself up so that, in retrospect, shameful events of the past lose their terror and seem merely unfortunate lapses in judgment. In looking back to the savagery of the Hollywood blacklist in the late 1940's and 50's, w...
docs.lead_paragraph: History has a way of cleaning itself up so that, in retrospect, shameful events of the past lose their terror and seem merely unfortunate lapses in judgment. In looking back to the savagery of the Hollywood blacklist in the late 1940's and 50's, when anti-Communist hysteria swept the country and many talented filmmakers were driven out of the industry, it's easy to forget the intensity of the paranoia and the viciousness of the persecution. The British director Karl Francis's film ''One of the Hollywood 10,'' which has its New York premiere on Sunday at the Walter Reade Theater, brings the era back in all its horror. The movie, a highlight of the 11th annual New York Jewish Film Festival, evokes a time of mob violence and sinister, goonlike government agents hounding suspected Communists day and night. It also reminds us of the virulent anti-Semitism that helped fuel those witch hunts, and the anti-Semitic slurs hurled across the screen still feel like stinging slaps in the face.
docs.abstract: Stephen Holden reviews movie One of the Hollywood 10, directed by Karl Francis, about anti-Communist hysteria of late 1940's and 1950's; Jeff Goldblum stars as director Herbert Biberman, who went to jail for refusing to disavow Communist beliefs; Greta Scacchi plays his wife, Oscar-winning actress Gale Sondergaard, whose career was also destroyed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show. Museums * ''AMERICAN RADIANCE: THE RALPH ESMERIAN GIFT'' AND ''DARGER: THE HENRY DARGER COLLECTION,'' American Folk Art Museum, 45 West 53rd Street, (212) 265-1040 (through June 2 and June 23, respectively). This 40-year-old museum finally has a home of its own and is celebrating its new quarters by showcasing two important recent gifts. The 400 objects of traditional folk art from Ralph Esmerian include extraordinary caches of portraits and needlework as well as walking sticks, painted furniture, frakturs, ceramics and weather vanes. Rife with acknowledged masterpieces, they raise the museum's collection to a new level while giving folk art itself a new visibility on the city's artscape. The Henry Darger gift, which includes 27 large two-sided watercolors and seven bound volumes by this Chicago recluse, counters the comforts of traditional folk art with a strong dose of the outsider variety, art made for an insatiable community of one. Reflecting the expanding folk-art field, the shows symbolize where the museum comes from and where it is going. Together they indicate that it intends to leave nothing behind. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, to 8 p.m. Admission: $9; $5, students and 62+ (Roberta Smith).

docs.lead_paragraph: After nearly a decade leading the Donmar Warehouse, the small London playhouse that helped make him a major cultural figure in Britain and abroad, Sam Mendes is preparing his goodbyes. ''It's time for a new generation to step in and take over,'' Mr. Mendes, 36, said in his office around the corner from the Donmar, the studio in Covent Garden that he has run since October 1992. The man once described on an almost weekly basis as a British theatrical wunderkind has gone on to direct movies, winning the 2000 Oscar for best director for ''American Beauty,'' his debut film. His attention turned back to his first home, that of the stage, between trips to and from Los Angeles, where he is applying the finishing touches to a new movie.

docs.lead_paragraph: Here's some consolation for the Oscar nominees for best screenplay who don't get the prize this March: odds are that they'll live longer than the winner, according to a new study in The British Journal of Medicine. The study, by Dr. Donald A. Redelmeier and Dr. Sheldon M. Singh of Sunnybrook and Women's Hospital in Toronto, was included in the journal's year-end roundup of quirky research. Many studies have shown that more successful people have longer lives, including work by Dr. Redelmeier and Dr. Singh that found Oscar-winning actors outlived mere nominees.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Hollywood producer Lynda Obst says the life of a producer boils down to this: rejection, endurance, lunch. Success is always suspect. ''Today's hero can quickly become tomorrow's goat,'' she says. Besides being a successful producer (''Sleepless in Seattle,'' ''The Fisher King,'' the television mini-series ''The Sixties''), Ms. Obst is the author of ''Hello, He Lied: And Other Truths From the Hollywood Trenches,'' a sharp and amusing 1996 memoir of her movie business life. She's also executive producer and host of a frisky television documentary based on her book, being shown tomorrow night on American Movie Classics.
docs.abstract: Julia Salamon reviews television program Hello, He Lied: And Other Truths From the Hollywood Trenches; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Argentina today formally abandoned a decade-long policy of linking its peso to the American dollar at a value of one to one, an arrangement that brought an initial, illusory burst of prosperity but departs with the country bankrupt and on the brink of political chaos. Eduardo Duhalde, Argentina's fifth president in little more than two weeks, sought the change on Friday as part of a broader ''public emergency law'' giving him sweeping powers to deal with the collapse. Acting in record time, the lower house of Congress approved the plan without significant alterations before dawn today, and the Senate followed suit this evening.

headline.main: Argentina Unlinks Peso From Dollar, Bracing for Devaluation and Even Harder Times
